title: All the ice on earth becomes water overnight, what happens next? - Quora

response.answer_text: Comes down to what you b.l.e.v.e. is next for Earth. To me, there would be no next for Earth and sea-level is irrelevant.  Sorry. If that happened the Gamilons sucker punched Earth with all it’s planet bombs all at once and our only hope rests with the valiant crew making the round trip to the planet Iskandar, one hundred and eighty six thousand light years away, and back in one year. (yeah, we’re screwed)  Even on Starblazers(1979)/Space Battleship Yamato (Anime 1974, Live action movie 2010) the attack on Earth took years.  The transition of ice into water requires the combination of temperature and time. For it to occur faster requires more temperature. Which brings up a common question, what is heat and what is heat transfer? Have you ever melted snow on a winter campfire for a cup of powdered hot chocolate or a cup of tea? I have. Hope you’re not in a hurry. Snow is insulating and ice doesn’t have a great heat transfer coefficient. Heat isn’t temperature but let’s consider a thought exercise. Let’s disregard the ice in the cirrus clouds and just stick with ice on the ground. Let’s take a google average “Lapse rate” of 6.5 °C/km.  I live in a place where when spring hits it hovers around 0°C (32°F) plus minus a few degrees day/night and it takes a couple months for the snow to melt. If it’s warm enough for the top of Denali to be at or near freezing, I’m a puddle on the floor. Most of the world’s population are dead. Heat, heat flux and temperature are very different things. This isn’t even considering the kilometers thick ice in Antarctica. For there to be enough heat to melt all ice on Earth overnight then likely there are parts of the Earth where lakes and rivers are literally boiling, the dry parts simply incinerate, and all life on Earth is destroyed. Even the oxygen reacts out and our Earth is a CO2 rustball. Sea-level is irrelevant. The oceans B.L.E.V.E. and the Earth is a deep fried frozen turkey.  (Water-bears and some bacteria deep in the crust might survive)

According to Al Gore it already happened. In 2013. All the polar bears (and presumably penguins) died, all the ports on earth are now flooded, most of the arable land is laying waste, billions of people are starving to death, and civilization has collapsed. We are now living in a post apocalyptic world and no one is reading this question or answer…. No…wait…the model he based his prediction on was wrong…. The great collapse will happen in (what is it now?) eight or ten years per Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. Honest…this time the model is right. Unless we turn all our resources over to the Global Warming hysterics the end of the world is just around the corner…ya-think…?!?!?

The way that might happen would have to have been enormously exothermic. Everybody died then, and the world eventually recovered. It was a major reset. After a million years, octopus eventually became the top level intelligence on the planet, figured out how to acquire the eternal life regeration trick from eternal jellyfish and eventually moved off the planet to conquer the milky way galaxy.

Let me change the question to something more sensible. Suppose a massive chunk of ice fell into the ocean from a glacier located in the antarctic. What happens next? This would produce a large tsunami that would cause massive damage to a large part of the world’s coastal regions. The ocean would then rise by a meter or so, depending on how much fell into the ocean. NB. The ice would not need melt, only fall into the ocean. When it actually melts this does not raise the ocean level at all.
All the ice on earth becomes water overnight, what happens next? Oh! dear no cubes to put in the whiskey.

Assuming a magical event turned all ice to water overnight, everything less than about 280 above sea level would end up under water. There would be some tsunami events that would wash over some higher regions before things settled down.
